title: Wild boars and ruined abbeys in the overlooked alternative to the Cotswolds
text:
Millions flock to the Cotswolds each year, turning villages like Bibury and Bourton-on-the-Water into very picturesque coach stations. Stay on the A40 for another hour, however, and you’ll find yourself in an uncrowded and utterly enchanting alternative.

You won’t find Instagrammers, selfie sticks, Jeremy Clarkson or a branch of Soho House in the Forest of Dean. Instead it offers simple pleasures: cosy cabins without Wi-Fi, hearty food in unfussy pubs, and long walks through ancient woodland – with the chance of spotting skittish deer and even wild boar.

Wild boar in England?

The Forest of Dean has become something of a rewilding trailblazer. Last month 18 pine martens were released at a secret location in the forest, and the cute porkers – hunted to extinction across the UK in the 13th century – reestablished themselves in the region around 20 years ago. Today it has Britain’s largest wild boar population (around 1,500), giving walkers a fair chance of a sighting.
